messageBody:
You are right about the ugliness of testing existing classes. If I try to
make one Junit test for one of our existing classes, I end up either (a)
putting a lot of code in the setup() method that gets used by only some of
the test methods or (b) not using the setup() and teardown() at all since
the data setup is completely different for each method to test. Plus there
is other problems with not being familiar with the class and the large
amounts of database setup that has to occur.

Is the intention of each Junit test to test one CLASS? And if so, should
each method in a Junit class correspond to a test of one public method in
the class it is testing? I think this is the case, but our existing code
does not lend itself easily to this. So I take it that (a.) all classes
should be designed so that they can be unit tested with ONE testcase (b.)
where all the code in the setup() and teardown() are useful for each of the
test methods in the class and (c.) there should be ONE test method
corresponding to each public method in the class being tested?

Assuming the above is true, how would I test the following: If I have one
test method for the constructor, and one test method for each of the methods
that act on that constructed object, the setup() and teardown() code becomes
really ugly because I need to setup data (requires A LOT of database setup)
for the constructor and I need to use the constructor method itself for the
setup() to test the other methods.
...I think the answer is that I should not test that constructor in that
unit test, and instead I should have a completely different unit test for
the creation of the object (it would be a unit test of a Factory object)?


Is there ever a VALID case when a one-to-one correspondence of
class-to-unit-test should not make sense? Can you ever make a properly
designed class that would require 4 or 5 completely different unit tests?
If so, these 4 or 5 tests sound like functional tests rather than 'unit'
tests, and does this tell me that my class wasn't defined correctly in the
first place, and that I need to 'refactor' it?

One thing to watch out for: Existing classes that are hard to test!

I've built tests on existing code and frequently I see classes that
are very hard to test. This happens because the classes were
originally developed without Unit Testing in mind. For a class to be
easy to test, it needs to follow good Object Oriented Design
practices where the class is well encapsulated and has little
coupling with other classes.

[Note: I've also seen Unit Testing improve the design. Making the
classes testable makes for better encapsulation and lower coupling]

Putting Unit Tests on existing code can get very ugly. Some classes
may not be worth Unit Testing until they are first refactored into
something more easily tested. This refactoring is beneficial but
costly. You will have to make the cost-benefit determination to see
if you should Unit Test the difficult code, refactor it, defer it.
